intro: Sisymbrium catholicum, commonly known as the sacred mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other mustard plants, and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and pinnately divided leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces pods that contain several seeds. Its botanical features include a taproot system and hairy stems, which help it survive in various soil conditions. Sisymbrium catholicum is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields.
